name: Tyson
line: Yes, you could get tsunamis that could take out coastal cities if it lands close to a continental shelf. But the chances of it hitting are about one in a million.

name: Interviewer
line: But you're cataloging this very closely. And we talked a little bit about the trajectory of what we think this asteroid is. Describe to us geographically where we think it will go, and where it might hit.

name: Tyson
line: Well, there are tens of thousands of asteroids orbiting safely out in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. And there is a subset of them that have orbits that come close to Earth. name: Interviewer
line: And you've brought evidence of that?

name: Tyson
line: I've got evidence of one. This is a meteorite. It's very heavy.

name: Interviewer
line: You're not kidding. This is very dense.

name: Tyson
line: This is part of the meteorite that made the famous crater in Arizona, meteor crater, formerly known as Barringer (ph) crater. And that one happens to be made of iron. Iron asteroids stay together in one piece all the way through Earth's atmosphere. And they leave big craters.

name: Tyson
line: But there are other kinds that might break up in the atmosphere and leave an air blast and render whole regions of Earth ablaze by the deposit of energy, right spontaneously into the atmosphere.

name: Interviewer
line: You tend to associate with people who care a lot about these matters. What does it say to you that this kind of story got the most hits on CNN.com? There's a tremendous degree of interest in it.

name: Tyson
line: Yes, well, of course. Survival matters. And to the extent that media pays attention to these kinds of risks. By the way, they are low probability, high consequence events.

name: Interviewer
line: Right. So how do you prepare for them?

name: Tyson
line: Well...

name: Interviewer
line: It's not like you can go out and buy a suit that's going to protect you...

name: Tyson
line: ... swat you like a bug if that hits you. What you need is a healthy space program, because the day is going to come, if we find one with our name on it, we want to go up and at least nudge it out of harm's way. That will take technology. That will take time. There is only a couple of dozen people in the world today who are monitoring the sky for these asteroids. That's not enough, as far as I am concerned.
